## Background

This report aims at mapping underemployment trends for employees and self-employed workers in the UK. We use the UKâ€™s largest study on employment circumstances, the Labour Force Survey (LFS), drawing on analysis from the 2006 to 2022 releases (calendar quarters). Our analyses consider only those in employment  between 18 and 64 years old.

```{r sample, echo=FALSE}

N_total <- LFS_clean %>% 
  group_by(as_factor(year), 
           as_label(quarter)) %>%
  summarise(Population = sum(na.omit(PWT[AGE >= 18 & AGE <= 64])), # everyone between 18 to 64
            Active = sum(PWT[ILODEFR <=2 & AGE >= 18 & AGE <= 64]), # in employment and unemployed between 18 to 64
            Workers = sum(PWT[ILODEFR == 1 & INECAC05 <= 2 & AGE >= 18 & AGE <= 64])) %>% # employee and self-employees between 18 to 64
  rename(Year = `as_factor(year)`,
         Quarter = `as_label(quarter)`) # Total population estimates
  
```


In this bulletin, low and high pay are calculated using the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) definitions . Low pay is defined as the value that is two-thirds of median hourly earnings and high pay is defined as the value that is 1.5 times median hourly earnings.


```{r low earners table}

options(digits = 3)

t_low_earners <- LFS_clean %>% # summary table
  filter(AGE >= 18 & AGE <= 64) %>% 
  filter(ILODEFR == 1) %>% # only people in employment
  filter(INECAC05 %in% c("1")) %>% #only employees
  filter(HOURPAY > 0 & SUMHRS > 0) %>%
  group_by(year, sequence, quarter) %>%
  summarise(median_pay = weighted_median(HOURPAY, weights = PIWT),
            low_pay = 2*(weighted_median(HOURPAY, weights = PIWT))/3,
            low_earner_men_median = sum(PIWT[SEX == 1 & HOURPAY <= low_pay]),
            low_earner_women_median = sum(PIWT[SEX == 2 & HOURPAY <= low_pay])) %>%
  as_label(.) %>%
  rename(Men = low_earner_men_median,
         Women = low_earner_women_median) %>%
  pivot_longer(c(Men, Women), names_to = "sex", values_to = "total")
  

```

```{r}

set.seed(300, sample.kind="Rounding")

data_ptime <- LFS_clean %>% # summary table
  filter(AGE >= 18 & AGE <= 64) %>% 
  filter(ILODEFR == 1) %>% # only people in employment
  filter(INECAC05 %in% c(1)) %>% #only employees
  filter(FTPTWK == 2) %>% # only part-timers
  filter(YPTJOB %in% c(3, 4)) %>%
  filter(!is.na(YPTJOB)) %>%
  filter(HOURPAY > 0 & SUMHRS > 0) %>%
  filter(!is.na(HOURPAY))


fit_rtree <- train(factor(YPTJOB) ~ HOURPAY, data = data_ptime,
                   method = "rpart",
                   tuneGrid = data.frame(cp = seq(0, 0.05, len = 25)))

ggplot(fit_rtree, highlight = TRUE)


```
